docs.text: About Model Intercomparison Projects (MIPs) ¶ Model Intercomparison Projects (MIPs) are coordinated climate modeling activities that bring together modeling groups from around the world to address specific scientific questions. MIPs are essential for: Advancing Climate Science : By comparing different models running the same experiments, we can better understand climate processes and reduce uncertainties in climate projections Standardizing Methodologies : MIPs establish common protocols, forcing datasets, and output requirements that enable meaningful comparisons across models Building Community : They foster collaboration among modeling centers, creating a shared infrastructure for climate research Supporting Policy : MIP results, particularly from CMIP (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project), form the scientific basis for IPCC assessment reports Using This Template ¶ This template provides a ready-to-use website structure for your MIP using MkDocs with the modern Shadcn theme. Activating GitHub Pages ¶ To publish your MIP documentation website: Go to your repository on GitHub Click on Settings → Pages Under "Source", select the gh-pages branch Select the / (root) folder Click Save Your site will be published at: https://<your-username>.github.io/<repository-name>/ Finding Your Website ¶ Once GitHub Pages is activated: Your site will be available at the URL shown in the GitHub Pages settings The site will automatically update whenever you push changes to the main branch Multiple versions are supported through mike (see developer documentation) Quick Links ¶ Developer Documentation - Learn how to customize this template Updating Content - Guide to adding and modifying pages GitHub Repository - Source code and issues Getting Started ¶ To customize this template for your MIP: Clone this repository Update the site information in mkdocs.yml Modify the content in the docs/ folder Push changes to see them reflected on your website For detailed instructions, see the Developer Documentation .

docs.text: This guide will help you set up and customize this MkDocs template for your MIP (Model Intercomparison Project). Prerequisites ¶ Before you begin, ensure you have: Python 3.8 or higher installed Git installed A GitHub account Basic knowledge of Markdown Initial Setup ¶ 1. Clone the Repository ¶ git clone https://github.com/WCRP-CMIP/MIP-template-theme.git cd MIP-template-theme 2. Install Dependencies ¶ pip install -r requirements.txt This will install: mkdocs - The static site generator mkdocs-shadcn - The modern Shadcn theme mike - For versioning your documentation pymdown-extensions - Additional Markdown features 3. Preview Locally ¶ To preview your site locally: mkdocs serve Then open your browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000/ The site will automatically reload when you make changes to the documentation files. Project Structure ¶ MIP-template-theme/ ├── docs/ # Documentation source files │ ├── index.md # Home page │ └── developers/ # Developer documentation ├── mkdocs.yml # MkDocs configuration ├── requirements.txt # Python dependencies └── .github/ └── workflows/ # GitHub Actions for auto-deployment Configuration ¶ Updating Site Information ¶ Edit mkdocs.yml to customize your site: site_name: Your MIP Name # Change this to your MIP name site_description: Your description site_author: Your organization repo_url: https://github.com/your-org/your-repo repo_name: your-org/your-repo Theme Customization ¶ The Shadcn theme can be customized in mkdocs.yml : theme: name: shadcn palette: primary: blue # Change color scheme accent: cyan Next Steps ¶ Learn how to update content Read the MkDocs documentation Explore mkdocs-shadcn theme options Learn about mike versioning

docs.text: This guide explains how to add, modify, and organize content in your MIP documentation site. File Organization ¶ All documentation files are stored in the docs/ directory as Markdown ( .md ) files. docs/ ├── index.md # Home page ├── developers/ # Developer documentation folder │ ├── getting-started.md │ └── updating-content.md └── your-folder/ # Add your own folders └── your-page.md Adding a New Page ¶ 1. Create the Markdown File ¶ Create a new .md file in the docs/ directory or a subfolder: # Create a new page echo "# My New Page" > docs/my-page.md # Or create in a folder mkdir -p docs/about echo "# About Our MIP" > docs/about/overview.md 2. Add to Navigation ¶ Edit mkdocs.yml and add your page to the nav section: nav: - Home: index.md - About: - Overview: about/overview.md - My New Page: my-page.md - Developers: - Getting Started: developers/getting-started.md - Updating Content: developers/updating-content.md 3. Preview Your Changes ¶ mkdocs serve Visit http://127.0.0.1:8000/ to see your changes. Markdown Basics ¶ Headings ¶ # Heading 1 ## Heading 2 ### Heading 3 Links ¶ [Link text](https://example.com) [Internal link](../other-page.md) Lists ¶ - Bullet point 1 - Bullet point 2 - Nested item 1. Numbered item 1 2. Numbered item 2 Code Blocks ¶ ```python def hello_world(): print("Hello, World!") ``` Images ¶ ![Alt text](images/my-image.png) Place images in docs/images/ folder. Advanced Features ¶ Admonitions (Call-outs) ¶ !!! note This is a note admonition. !!! warning This is a warning. !!! tip This is a helpful tip. Tables ¶ | Column 1 | Column 2 | Column 3 | |----------|----------|----------| | Data 1 | Data 2 | Data 3 | | Data 4 | Data 5 | Data 6 | Publishing Changes ¶ Automatic Deployment ¶ When you push changes to the main branch, GitHub Actions will automatically: Build your documentation Deploy it to GitHub Pages using mike Make it available at your GitHub Pages URL git add . git commit -m "Update documentation" git push origin main Manual Build ¶ To manually build the site: # Build static site mkdocs build # Deploy to GitHub Pages with versioning mike deploy --push --update-aliases 0.1 latest mike set-default --push latest Versioning with Mike ¶ Mike allows you to maintain multiple versions of your documentation: # Deploy a new version mike deploy --push 1.0 latest # List all versions mike list # Set default version mike set-default --push latest # Delete a version mike delete --push 0.9 Tips for Organizing Content ¶ Use folders for related content (e.g., tutorials/ , reference/ , about/ ) Keep filenames simple and use hyphens (e.g., getting-started.md , not Getting Started.md ) Use descriptive headings to improve navigation Link between pages to create a connected documentation experience Add images to the docs/images/ folder Getting Help ¶ MkDocs Documentation Markdown Guide PyMdown Extensions Mike Documentation
